user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketSendTo:
```c
int32 OS_SocketSendTo(osal_id_t sock_id, const void *buffer, size_t buflen, const OS_SockAddr_t *RemoteAddr)
{
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *stream;
    OS_object_token_t            token;
    int32                        return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(buffer);
    OS_CHECK_SIZE(buflen);
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(RemoteAddr);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_REFCOUNT, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sock_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        stream = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, token);

        if (stream->socket_type != OS_SocketType_DATAGRAM)
        {
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE;
        }
        else
        {
            return_code = OS_SocketSendTo_Impl(&token, buffer, buflen, RemoteAddr);
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketSendTo:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_CHECK_SIZE(val) ARGCHECK((val)>0&&(val)<(UINT32_MAX/2),OS_ERR_INVALID_SIZE)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_stream_internal_record_t OS_stream_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct
{
    char   stream_name[OS_MAX_PATH_LEN];
    uint8  socket_domain;
    uint8  socket_type;
    uint16 stream_state;
} OS_stream_internal_record_t
...
int32 OS_SocketSendTo_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const void *buffer, size_t buflen,
                           const OS_SockAddr_t *RemoteAddr)
{
    int                             os_result;
    socklen_t                       addrlen;
    const struct sockaddr *         sa;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    sa = (const struct sockaddr *)&RemoteAddr->AddrData;
    switch (sa->sa_family)
    {
        case AF_INET:
            addrlen = sizeof(struct sockaddr_in);
            break;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
        case AF_INET6:
            addrlen = sizeof(struct sockaddr_in6);
            break;
#endif
        default:
            addrlen = 0;
            break;
    }

    if (addrlen != RemoteAddr->ActualLength)
    {
        return OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS;
    }

    os_result = sendto(impl->fd, buffer, buflen, MSG_DONTWAIT, sa, addrlen);
    if (os_result < 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("sendto: %s\n", strerror(errno));
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return os_result;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE (-36)
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
Fragments not listed above were reviewed and considered not relevant to a potential MISRA C:2023 Rule 2.1 (unreachable code) violation for the following reasons: 

- Simple straight-line statements (e.g. variable declarations, assignments like return_code = OS_SocketSendTo_Impl(...);, the final return return_code;) are syntactically reachable depending on control flow and do not themselves create unreachable code.

- The return statements and error-path branches inside OS_ObjectIdGetById are conventional early returns used for error handling; they are reachable for some inputs and so do not constitute unreachable code by themselves.

- Macro expansions for OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET and OS_ObjectIndexFromToken are index/address expressions that are evaluated at runtime and do not introduce statically unreachable code.

- The sendto() call and its error handling are runtime-dependent (based on os_result) and therefore reachable under appropriate conditions.

The selected fragments were chosen because they are places where unreachable code could be introduced implicitly or conditionally: (1) the OS_CHECK_* macros expand to BUGCHECK/ARGCHECK (not shown) which may implement non-returning behavior, making subsequent statements effectively unreachable; (2) the object-id transaction/init/convert/cancel flow contains early returns and cancellation paths that can alter control flow and potentially leave later code unreachable; (3) the OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET usage interacts with token expressions and could hide mismatches or misuse that lead to unreachable code; and (4) the switch on sa_family combined with conditional compilation (#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6) can change which case labels exist and thus can make some case-specific code unreachable in certain builds.  These locations should be investigated to ensure no build/configuration or macro expansion produces unreachable code anywhere in the project.
